awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Metal Fueled Hall Effect Thruster Using A Radioisotope Heater
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Phase I project is to significantly alter the current state of electric propulsion by providing a thruster platform with extended capabilities. Such a change would allow Hall thrusters to span a wider range of operating parameters with added benefits of increased efficiency, lower cost, exploration of deep space, and backup power via a radioisotope power system (RPS). By using a RPS, the thruster platform will produce one watt of electrical power for every nine watts of heating power. The heating power will enable the use of high-density metal propellants such as zinc. The electrical power will provide a backup for solar generation and can potentially power basic satellite systems. This work will provide scientific knowledge regarding nuclear fuel recycling, power generation, and related space technologies. Lastly, this work will be highly collaborative and will contribute to the training of a highly diverse workforce. 


	This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project addresses a longstanding issue in space propulsion; the reliance on xenon as a fuel. The primary objective of the proposed work is to produce a prototype Hall Effect thruster utilizing zinc fuel and a RPS unit. A thermal management system will manage the heat produced by the RPS unit to deliver fuel to the thruster. Initial work will use an electrical module that will act as a placeholder for the RPS unit; the latter can be inserted when necessary. Design of the prototype will follow Hall Effect thruster scaling laws to reduce risk. The results of the tested prototype will provide information on the expelled ions, thruster efficiency, and divergence of the thruster plume. More broadly, the results will provide data on realizing an alternative to xenon fuel for space propulsion as part of an improved thruster platform.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project's aim was to design and develop a metal fueled Hall effect thruster. This prototype thruster used an electrically heated fuel delivery system for supplying the thruster with zinc. A variety of fuels beyond the standard xenon were considered for this project with zinc being chosen due to its promise for efficiency and its positive chemical attributes. This Phase I project provided the necessary foundation from which a more advanced thruster may be developed. We designed a thruster for the medium power range, 1-5 kW as this would power a large class of satellites.

We simulated the heating system to inform our design. Two fueling modes were researched; sublimation which heats the solid fuel directly into a gas and vaporization which heats the solid fuel to a liquid and further heats the liquid to a gas. Sublimation was chosen as the fueling mechanism based on a number of constraints in our project. Analysis from the ANSYS simulation is included in this report.

The thruster was fabricated at a level equal to a breadboard laboratory prototype. The thruster was situated for testing inside a custom vacuum chamber which achieved an appropriate pressure to reflect in-space conditions. Some subsystems of the thruster were tested in this environment. Gas propellants, argon and xenon, were planned for testing to ensure the thruster components work individually before switching to zinc. A picture of the thruster inside the testing chamber is shown as a picture attached to this report.

Some plasma diagnostics such as a Langmuir probe and energy analyzer were developed to understand the plasma behavior of the thruster. These two diagnostics yield information of the energy of the expelled ions, electron temperature and density, and the electric potential structure of the plasma. Further optical based diagnostics are under development for more advanced understanding of the system.

Considerable time was spent on understanding the business segment for the innovation. We participated in the NSF bootcamp entrepreneurial training program and interviewed several possible customers of our innovation. In preparation for future work, we are forming a strategy for realizing our beachhead market and subsequent commercialization.

The project contributed to human resource development by providing highly skilled training to two young scientists. Improving the national security and capability of the workforce was an important goal of this project. Both (recent B.S. graduates) learned a variety of skills including: computer aided design (CAD), simulations, and experimental design. Further, an emphasis was placed on creative thought and problem solving in order to tackle a number of societal problems in the arena of space. During the project period, personnel attended relevant conferences for professional development.

 


Last Modified: 09/25/2023
Modified by: Evan Aguirre

Images (1 of )
  • Shown here is the completed Hall thruster prototype inside the vacuum chamber. The cathode is visible at the bottom, through a chamber port. The retarding field energy analyzer and Langmuir probe are visible at the top.
    E. M. Aguirre
    Creative Commons
    Evan Aguirre
    Hall Thruster
  • Shown here is the ANSYS simulated heating system of four cartridge heaters for a zinc slug. Multiple nodes throughout the system show the temperature (in Celsius) in a near steady state.
    E. M. Aguirre
    Creative Commons
    Evan Aguirre
    ANSYS heater simulation
